msItem.title: The Debate between the Body and the Soul
The Life and Passion of St. Blaise
The Life and Passion of St. Cecilia
Four lines of Middle English Verse
Allas deceyte, þat in truste ys nowe
Be þou nou&yogh;t tobolde to blame
Better ys to suffre and fortune abide
He þe wise and wel i tau&yogh;t

handNote.p: The first part of the manuscript, ff. 1r-200r written in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
The second part of the manuscript, ff. 200v-203v written in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
The third part of the manuscript, ff. 204r-228r written in the early thirteenth century.
The fourth part of the manuscript, ff. 204r-228r written in a compact textura hand of the early thirteenth century.

The fifth part of the manuscript, ff. 228v-237v written in the late fourteenth century in a script of the same type and date (Anglicana) as that of Cambridge, Magdalene College, Pepys, MS 2498 and London, British Library, Laud Misc. MS 622.
In the sixth part of the manuscript, the top of f. 238 is in a hand of the fifteenth century.
In the sixth part of the manuscript, the verses on the rest of f. 238 are also in a hand of the fifteenth century.
On one flyleaf, f. iii recto, a fourteenth-century hand writes a prayer in Latin.

On one flyleaf, f. iii recto, a fifteenth-century hand has written a contents list, seemingly for a different manuscript, which has been inserted within the leaf. Note: another hand (different style of final s, for example) has traced over the first few lines; whether the tracing hand has contributed writing of its own is not known.

origin.p: ff. 1-198r are written in a W Oxon dialect from around the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
ff. 204r-219v are written in a W Norfolk dialect from around c. 1300.
ff. 219v-228r are written in a W Norfolk dialect with a substratum from SE Surrey, SW Kent, or N Suffolk, from around c. 1300.
ff. 228v-237v were written around the late fourteenth century.
The verses on f. 238 were written in the fifteenth century.

provenance.p: The manuscript was owned by Henry Perveys around 1450-1475.
The manuscript was owned by William Laud in 1633.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated to the Bodleian Library by William Laud in 1635.

bibl.ref: All items belong to the LAEME literary category.

þat power he &yogh;af p P eter þo&punctelev; and alle ís oþere fere,

And alle þe p p&combtildevert; pre latu&slong; of holíe churche : þat after him &slong;ethþe come; The word "holie" in this line represents the scribe's frequent tendency to place the acute-like i-dot over the following glyph. I have not attempted to represent this in the transcriptions. It seems to me that it is best associated with the facsimile layer.
þ Þ arefo&rrot;e ech man heom &slong;cholde a bowíe : þat guode &yogh;eme þarof nome.

p P eter p P eter o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde,&punctelev; to IJ erusalem í mot wende There are two folds running down the middle of the parchment from the top of the text down to poetic) line 56 on the left and poetic line 79 on the right. In most cases, there is no uncertainty about the reading but the "s" in "seide" in this line is the first where it needs to be noted. I have not indicated letters affected by these folds unless they are considerably obscured. This note should probably be moved (to right before the next <pb/> element?).
And soffrí muche fo&rrot; mankuínde&punctelev; and þane deth aten ende

s S
Seínt Peter him ladde in conseílle,&punctelev; and seíde louerd þín ore

g G o bí h&ydot;nde me o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde&punctelev; þou spext a&slong;e mí fo The fold in the parchment hides the "i" in "seide", but the acute-like dot is visible over the "d", confirming the reading.

þ þ ou no&slong;t nou&yogh;t &yogh;wat to gode bifallez&punctelev; ne onder&slong;tonde&slong;t no þe mo This line and the following three lines have a corrupt tile in the digital image. Readings should be checked against the TIFF file.

h H o &slong;o co
cometh after me&punctelev; hím &slong;eelf he mot fo&rrot;&slong;ake The tip of a large triangular hole in the manuscript begins after the first two letters in "cometh". The scribe appears to have begun the word and then thought better of it, starting the word anew on the other side of the hole without erasing the inital "co" he had already written.
h H ís O o wene rode bere and s&ydot;wí me&punctelev; and he wolle to me take

And apeiri ís &slong;elíe &slong;oule&punctelev; me þ&ydot;nchez he bí &yogh;ít wel lu&ydot;te

c Cri &slong;t&punctelev; þe maydene&slong; &slong;one Maríe I have used the combining mark ̅ for the abbreviation of Jesu, since the stroke does not cross the "h"; it is more like a macron between the "h" and the following vowel. The abbreviation of "Crist" looks like "c" with a minim directly above it. I have used  &openparen;COMBINING LATIN SMALL LETTER DOTLESS I&closeparen; for this mark, but note that this is a PRIVATE USE AREA code point.

Note that French stressed final "e" is represented with an acute accent in the critical transcription.
Are ch beo to heuene i went þat &yogh;e ne &slong;eon nou&yogh;t me
A&slong;e þeos de&slong;ciple&slong; to gadere weren heo maden contek and mone Lines 89-90 appear to omit the acute-like dot over i in a systematic manner.

l.note: Approximately 22 lines are missing from the beginning of the page. At this point, a small piece of parchment still bound contains an unidentifiable fragment of an ornamental capital in blue ink, touched with red. Beneath it, presumably the following line is a capital "A", touched with red. Were these remnants to be lineated, they would presumably be lines 103-104, and this is indicated in their @xml:id, albeit with a suffix "a" so that the current lineation can be preserved. If Horstmann transcribed these fragments, they were lost in our OCR.
Another 27 or so lines have been lost due to the tearing of the page. Another fragment remains, probably starting with part of a capital "A" at line 131a.

l.unclear: ut þa oþur bit at þ
l.note: Lines 132a-135a are incomplete, as the parchment is torn on the right before the caesura. Line 132a is torn at more or less the point where the ascenders of letters begin. The presence of distinct thorn descenders make it possible to read the text with some confidence, the least distinct letters being the "b" in "bit", which might be an "s", and the "t" in "at".

div1.l:
þ Þ e oþur wolle ari&slong;e and late lette
Horstmann's emendation of "late" to "lette" may just be an accurate reading of a ligatured or crowded "ett".
Al&slong;o ít fareth of ouwer neode
And &slong;tudefa&slong;tlíche wíth gode

l.note: The folio is torn, with only fragments of lines 177a-180a remaining. There is evidence of about ten letters (including two spaces) in line 177a, but they are all but unreadable.

Mo&rrot;e to beon ícleoped þí &slong;one&punctelev; fo&rrot; ín pouerte ích me habbe íbrou&yogh;t

Hís fader let hím cloþí &slong;wíþe wel; &punctelev; gret fe&slong;te he makede and blí&slong;&slong;e The addition of "fader" after "his" is possibly in a hand of the fourteenth or fifteenth century. Horstmann describes it only as a "späterer Hand" (p. 34).

w W íth alle ís N n eí&yogh;ebore&slong; þare abo‸vte&punctelev; fo&rrot; I J oíe of ís &slong;one íwí&slong; The added "v" in "aboute" is accompanied by a sublinear caret. The hand might be that of the main scribe or of the later hand responsible for "fader" in the previous line.

And sethþe take a3en to me, : 3wane ich habbe mine schep ibrou3t.
Ne heore 3e alle, þis giwes seiden, : he spektþ ase he beo wod?
I wis þe deuel is him with Inne; : ne seo 3e he ne can no guod?
Heo wenden and gadereden stones anon : to henen him euerech one.
3wat eileth ou, ore louerd seide to heom, : to kene me with stones?
Mani guod dede ich ouhabbe i schewed, : and mani guod word al so.
For none god dede, þis giwes seiden, : to deþe we nellez þe do,
Ake for þou seist þat þou art god, : and art Man ase we beoth.
3if 3e wollez me i leue, orelouerd seide, : þat3e i nou3 al dai iseoth.
þe giwes him wolden nime anon; : ake stilleliche he fleu awei
Ouer þe watere of þe flum Jordan, for to is tyme were icome nei
Bi 3eonde þe watere he conseilede is desciples, : and with is fader he spac al so.
Bote þe corn of Swete beo ded, : þat is on eorþe ido,
Al one it bileueth with oute fruyt; : Ake 3if þat hit ded is,
þat is 3if it rotuth and chineth, : muche fruyt it bringez i wis.
Al þat he seide bi him self; : bote he þolede deth here,
No fruyt ne mi3te he bringe of soulene : to heuene his i fere.
For ore louered euenede him to 3wete, : and to oþur corne neuere,
þare fore of 3wete is þat swete flesch, : þat atþe masse imaked is euere.
Fader! he seide, make me cler and clene, : for nouþe sone is mi tyme iwis!
Sauue me and make cler, : for mi soule destourbed is!
A voiz þare cam and with him spak : fram is fader of heuene an hei,
And so cler him makede ase he bad, : þat no man him ne sei;
Gret soun heo heorden, ake non ne mi3te : iwite 3wat it were;
Some seiden þat it an Aungel was : þat with him spac þere,
And some þat it was þoundre, : þe wisore none nere.
þo bi gan ore louerd to schewi him, : and of is fadere heom lere.
Louerd! quath seint Phelip, it is inou3, : Ake lat us ene þine fader ise!
Phelip, ore louerd seide, ne knoustou me nou3t? : so longe þou hast with me ibeo;
Nostou nou3t þat mi fader is In me, : and ich in him al so?
And ich mot a3ein to him wende : þat me hath hidere ido?
3if 3e louieth me, 3e wollez witen : mine hestes, 3wodere so ich wende.
Mine fadere i chulle bidde þat he schal : oþur confort ou sende.
I nelle ou nou3t bi lene faderles; : þe holie gost ou comez to,
þat schal ou techen alle þing; : and mi pays ich ou 3iue al so,
Ich ou segge bi fore hond, : þat 3e þarof 3eme nome,
And þat 3e þe betere it i lefden, : 3wane it to eou come.
I nelle nou3t muche with ou speke, : ne mid ou bi leue longe;
For þe worldes maistrie comez ope me, : and in me ne schal nou3t afonge.
Ich am, he seide, a ri3t soth vine, : and mi fader teoliare is,
Ech braunche on me þat ne berez no fruit : a wei he wole caste i wis;
And þulke þat bereth fruyt puyrgi he wole, : þat it schal bere fruyt þe more.
3e beoth þe braunches, and ich þe vine; : are fruyt is forlore,
Asc þe braunche þat ne berez no fruyt, : bote heo beo In þe vine,
Ne 3e ne mowen bote3e beon in me, : ase 3e schulle iseon at þe fine.
þulke þat in me wonie nele, : i corue heo worth atþe laste
Ase a luþur braunche, and fur druyt, : and in þe fuyr man schal ire caste.
3e beoth mine freond, 3if 3e mine heste doth, : and mine þralles nou3t;
For a þral not nou3t is louerdes wille, : are is weork him beo ibrou3t;
Mi wille ich ou schewi bi foren hond; : I ches ov and 3e nout me.
Ne rechche 3e nout þei þe world ov hatie, : ne ne habbe ofou pite;
3e wuteth wel þat it hatede me bi fore; : he louez wel þat is his.
For ich habbe ou out of þe worlde inome, : þe world ou hatez i wis;
3if he me hatez and to deþe me doth, : ov he wole al so.
And 3if i nadde here mi sulf with him ispeke, : no sunne he nadde ido,
And 3eot 3if i nadde oþur dede i do, : þane ani Man euere mi3te;
Ake nov ne mai he excusi him nou3t, : þat is dedene ne beoth a3en ri3te.
Muche oþur þing ich habbe ou to segge; : acke 3e ne mowen nou3t .al bere nouþe.
þe holi gost schal come and techen ov : more þane 3e er couþe.
A luytel 3wyle it is to comene, : þat3e ne schulle i seo me nou3t;
And a luyte þer after 3e schullen me i seo, : 3wan ich am to liue i brou3t.
3e schullen beon sorie and wepen for me, wel glad þe world wole beo;
Ouwer soruwe into Joye schal tuyrne, ase 3e it schullen iseo.
A womman hath gret trauaile of childe : and gret sorewe middi wisse,
Ake a no þat heo sikth þat chil i bore, : hire wo heo fur 3it for blisse.
Also schulle 3e, 3wane 3e me i seoth : fram deþe arise to liue.
Ich cam fram mi fader into þe worlde, : and a3einich mot wel bliue.-
Nou sone ich worþe al one, for 3e wollez alle : to sprede and fram me fleo;
Ake 3e ne schullen lete me al one, : for mi fader wole mid me beo.
þis prechinge he made for is desciples, : are he scholde dei3e,
To wissi and to conforti heom, : ;wane heo þe soþe isei3e.
Vs and alle oþere he wissede also : of þe daie of dome
And of ore deþe þat we a redie weren, : for we nusten 3wane heo come.
þe kynedom of heuene, he seide, : ten Maidenes ilich heo is,
þat nomen heore laumpene and wenden forth : a;en heore spouse iwis.

div1.note: Here and below, I have used ﬅ to mark the st ligature. This is a standard Unicode codepoint for a letterform that seems to be showing up frequently; I think we should add it to our entities.
Top right of folio includes entry numeration 8. It is unclear in the scan whether the numeration is ink or crayon.

div1.l: Louerd heo seíden ondo þís &yogh;at &punctelev; and lat us I i nto þe come
I not nou&yogh;t eov quath þe louerd &punctelev; wíthoute &yogh;e schullen abide
And beoth eft íredíe fo&rrot; &yogh;e ne wuten &punctelev; þe daí ne þe tíde
þ Þ at was þat heo &slong;cholden aredíe beon &punctelev; a&yogh;eín þe daíe of dome
And a&yogh;en þe deþe fo&rrot; heo nu ﬅ &slong;t en &punctelev; &yogh;wuch tíme þat heo come
&YOGH;if heo abíden with heo&rrot;e guode weo&rrot;ke&slong; &punctelev; fo&rrot; to heo ícome were
þat 3at of heuene scholde beo faste imad, : ne scholde heo come in þere.
Ore louerd hath fíf wítte&slong; eche manne i&yogh;&ydot;ue &punctelev; þat he a&slong; wel bí&slong;ette
And þare wíth þat tre&slong;our of god dede &punctelev; to í&slong; &slong;oule bí &yogh;íte and fette
Ane bí tale he tolde of a man &punctelev; þat a pílegrímage wende
h H is tre&slong;o&rrot; he let b&rrot;inge fo&rrot;th &punctelev; and after ís &slong;erjaunz &slong;ende
Twe&ydot; be&slong;aunz he tok þat on &punctelev; þat oþur he tok fíue
þene þrídde he ne tok bote on &punctelev; þat &slong;cholden þat treso&rrot; dríue
He þat hadde fíue afonge &punctelev; þiat catel he drof a boute
Fiue oþur be&slong;aunz he bi&yogh;at &punctelev; þe &yogh;w&ydot;le ís louerd wa&slong; oute
He þat hadde tweíne afonge &punctelev; tweíne he bí&yogh;at al&slong;o
And he nadde bote on he nam hís &punctelev; and onder eo&rrot;þe ít gan do

And axede a counte&slong; of ís be&slong;aunz &punctelev; hou ít were þare of ígon

þ Þ at ate a counte&slong; a&slong;e a trewe &slong;eríaunt &punctelev; Into into þe Io&ydot;e io&ydot;e
of heuene he beo íbrou&yogh;t
A&slong;e o&rrot;e louerd p&rrot;echede í&slong; de&slong;cíple&slong; : and confo&rrot;tede heom adaí
Hít bífel þat lazar Lazar þe kní&yogh;t : In grete &slong;íkne&slong;&slong;e laí
In ís ca&slong;tel bí&slong;íde Betaníe : and í&slong; &slong;o&slong;terene tweíe
Martha and Maríe Maugdeleíne : ouer hím weren beíe
Ane daíe&slong; Jo&rrot;neíe iorneie ít wa&slong; : fram þe watere of Io&rrot;dan Jordan
&yogh;eot þís womman fo&rrot; heo&rrot;e broþer : to o&rrot;e louerd heo &slong;enden ane Man man
þat he come þudere &yogh;íf ít were ís wílle : and radde heom &slong;um red
þe &yogh;wíle þe me&slong;&slong;ager wa&slong; to o&rrot;e louerd ígo : lazar Lazar þe kní&yogh;t wa&slong; de ded
Tweí dawes o&rrot;e lou&combtildevert;uerd bí leuede &yogh;eot : are he þudere í wen wende
He let ís de&slong;cíple&slong; þana þrídde daí : gon wíth hím to Iude Jude
Louerd &slong;eíden heo &yogh;wat wolt þou þere : nellez þe gíwe&slong; sle þe
Nolden heo habbe íhend þe wíth &slong;tone&slong; : and þou wolt þudere eft&slong;one
&yogh;e nutez nou&yogh;t hou ít ís quad o&rrot;e louerd : ích habbe þare to done
Ich mot awechche lazar Lazar o&rrot;e frend : fo&rrot; aslepe he ís íbrou&yogh;t
&yogh;e &slong;eíden þe de&slong;cíple&slong; he maí awakíen, : þeí þou ne trauaíllíe nou&yogh;t
Naí &slong;eíde o&rrot;e louerd he ís ded : and þ&rrot;e dawes hath íbeo
&yogh;e í&slong;eothz nouþe þat ích wot alle þíng : þeí ích ít nou&yogh;t ne &slong;eo
Toward Iude Jude heo wenden fo&rrot;th : and lazare Lazare þare heo founde
Ded and ín a þ&rrot;ou&yogh; íleíd : In in dede manne&slong; &slong;chete íwounde
Hís &slong;o&slong;tren &slong;eten at hom aweopen : and of þe hexte gíwe&slong; &slong;ome
Martha heo&rrot;de telle þat o&rrot;e louerd wa&slong; : to þe þrouwe í come
To hím heo o&rrot;n and críde &yogh;eo&rrot;ne : and seíde louerd &yogh;wat í&slong; þí red
&yogh;íf þou hadde&slong;t here ero&rrot;e íbeo : mí broþer nere nou&yogh;t ded
Ake nov ích wot þat &yogh;wat þo bíddest : of god God he wole þe &yogh;íu
þo &slong;eíde o&rrot;e louerd : þí broþer &slong;chal : arí&slong;e &yogh;et and líue
Heo &slong;eíde : ích wot he &slong;chal a dome&slong;daí : aríse up ích íleue þe
Ich am quad o&rrot;e louerd oprí&slong;te and líjf : ho &slong;o wole bíleue on me
þeí he were ded &yogh;eot he &slong;chal líbbe : and ech man þat alíue ís
Mí&yogh;t þou Martha þís íleue : &yogh;e louerd quath heo
Ich wot þat þou art gode&slong; Godes &slong;one : þat ín þí&slong; wo&rrot;lde wo&slong;t wolt beo
þo o&rrot;n Martha to híre &slong;o&slong;ter hom : and bad híre þat heo wende
Stílle che liche and wíth o&rrot;e louerd &slong;peke : fo&rrot; A a ftur híre he &slong;ende
Maríe aro&slong; up &slong;tíllelíche : wel glad heo gan fo&rrot;th gon
þe gíwe&slong; þat h&ydot;re confo&rrot;tí &slong;cholden : heo þou&yogh;ten and &slong;eíden anon
Fram u&slong; heo geth þu&slong; &slong;tíllelíche : we wuten wel &yogh;wat ít ís
Síwe we híre &yogh;íf we mouwe : aní confo&rrot;t híre do·
Maríe cam to o&rrot;e louerd &slong;one : and þe gíwe&slong; wíth híre al f so
And þe gíwe&slong; weopen alle fo&rrot;th wíth híre : louerd heo &slong;eíde þín o&rrot;e
Maríe ful to o&rrot;e louerde&slong; fet : wepínde &slong;wíþe &slong;o&rrot;e
Mí broþer nadde nou&yogh;t íbeo ded : &yogh;íf þou hadde&slong;t íbeon hím neí&yogh;
þe gíwe&slong; &slong;eíden þo heo í&slong;eíen wepe : nov we mowe í&slong;eo
Hou muche he louede him : &yogh;wane he wole fo&rrot; him &slong;o &slong;o&rrot;i be
Ore louerd het heom þat heo þat lid : of þe þrouwe a wei bere.
Louerd! quath Martha, he stinkez foule, : four dawes he hath i beo þere,
Ne habbe ich iseid, quath ore louerd, : þat 3e mowe iseo
Godes mi3te, 3if 3e wollez : of gode bi leue beo?
þo þat lid was awei inome, : ore louerd bi heold up softe;
Fader! he seide, ich þonki þe : þat þou hast iherd me ofte;
I heor me nouþe and schev þi grace, : fader! ich bidde þe,
þat þis folk aboute i leue it wel : þat þou sendest hidere to me!
þo bi gan ore louerd loude to grede, : cum out, Lazar, a non!
He a ros up fram deþe to liue, : and hol gan forth gon,
With listene i bounde ase he was, : and In a cloth i wounde.
Mani giv turnede þare to god : for þe miracles þat heo founde.
Ore louerd het heom don a wei ech del : and late him gon on bounde.
þe apostles deliuereden him anon, : is limes were hole and sounde.
A non so ore louerd het Lazar come out, : as þe bok us doth telle,
þe bodi wende out of þrouwe a non, : and þe soule cam out of helle;
For seint Austin seith þat Lazar tolde : heom, þat weren him nei3,
Muche of þe priuete of helle, : þat he þare Inne i sei3.
þis word was sone wide ibrou3t : to þe heie maistres of þe lawe,
Hou ore louerd hadde Lazar a rerd; þat folk gan to him drawe.
Gret conseil heo maden a non : and seiden heom bi tuene:
3if we ani 3wyle þus lateth him gon, : he wole us don gret teone,
þis folk wole al to him tuyrne, : þe romains us wollez ouer come,
And þoru3 heom ore men and al heore lond : sone us worth bi nome.
Cayfas þat was hore bischop, : ase god wolde, he gan telle:
Betere is þat on deie for men, : þane al fok go into helle.
Of him sulf ne seide he nou3t þat, : for he wende wel to lie,
Ake ore louerd wolde þat he seide soth : In manere of prophecie.
Fram þulke time after ward : heo a waiteden wel bliue
To nimen ore louerd and Lazar : and bringe heom beine of liue.
Ore louerd wende with is desciples : bi side desert a luyte
Into þe cite of Effrem, : þare he bi lefde 3uyte.
þe feste of ester was ful nei3, þare fore eche daye ene
To þe temple þe giwes wenden : to make heom þare a3en clene,
And þou3ten also þat ore louerd wolde : sum time þudere come,
A3en þe heie feste, þat heo mi3ten : a waiti þat he were inome.
Heo leten crie oueral a boute, : 3if ani man mi3te onder 3ite
Ani þing of him in anie stude, : Men scholden heom do to wite.
A palmesonendayes eue ore louerd wende : to Martha and to Marie,
þare ase he Lazare arerde, : bi side Bethanie.
Symound leprous was a man : þat Musel hadde ibeo longe,
Ake ore louerd him hadde iheld bi fore : of is vueles þat weren stronge.
Jn is hous ore louerd lefde ate mete, : and is desciples also,
And Lazar þat he to liue brou3te, : and is sostrene two.-
